metadata.title: Detection and Occurrence of Indicator Organisms and Pathogens

abstract.text: A review of the literature published in 2009 is presented on topics related to occurrence and detection of fecal indicators and pathogens. This review is divided into three major sections: environmental occurrence, persistence, and transport; detection methods; and microbial source tracking. The first section is subdivided into persistence and transport of fecal indicator bacteria, particle association and transport, microbial quality of recreational beaches, occurrence of fecal indicators bacteria and pathogens in watersheds, irrigation systems, estuaries, and wetlands, and novel indicators. The second section describes the studies related to endpoint PCR and reverse transcription PCR, real-time PCR, loop mediated isothermal amplification, array based genetic and phenotype based diagnostics, and genotyping. The third section covers genotypic and phenotypic microbial source tracking methods.

body_text.text: water. In one study, quantitative PCR (qPCR) was used to measure the effect of water filtration, fecal aggregate size, fecal concentration and temperature on the persistence of Bacteroides 16S rRNA markers (Bell et al., 2009) . Three experimental types were considered for this study; unfiltered stream water with fecal slurry, filtered water with fecal slurry, and unfiltered water without fecal slurry.

Three different aggregate sizes-coarse, medium and fine were tested. There was no effect of aggregate size observed on the persistence of Bacteroides markers. Starting concentrations of 10, 100 and 1000 mg/L of fecal slurry were used to observe the time required for decay. The 1000 mg/L microcosm decayed much slower than the 10 and 100 mg/L. Lower temperatures of 5, 10 and 15 o C as well as 35 o C were evaluated in the experiment. The time taken for decay was slower at lower temperatures as compared to higher temperatures for Bacteroides markers in unfiltered stream water. Temperature had a significant effect on the decay rate of all experimental microcosms studied.

There has been interest in developing alternate indicators for fecal contamination. Two human (HF134, HF 183) and two ruminant (CF128, CF193) fecal Bacteroidales markers were studied for the persistence and the survival of the marker cells in freshwater microcosms (Walters and Field, 2009) . QPCR was employed to measure DNA marker persistence in light and dark cycles. The two human-specific Bacteroidales markers did not show any differences in persistence in the light and dark microcosms.

However, with the ruminant-specific Bacteroidales markers there were significant differences. CF128 persisted until day 14 where as CF 193 were detected until day 3 and day 6 in light and dark microcosms, respectively. CF128 was not affected by light unlike CF193. The persistence of ruminant-specific markers was longer than human-specific markers. Also, the ruminant-specific marker cells showed longer survival rates compared to the human-specific marker cells.

Another similar study was carried out to assess the persistence of fecal Bacteroidales in unchlorinated drinking water using qPCR (Saunders et al., 2009) . Freshwater sediment microcosms were studied for the survival and persistence of E. coli, total coliforms and enterococci . Sediments from Bay of Vidy, Switzerland (rich in nutrients), Lake Bret (eutrophic) and Versoix River in Lake Geneva (nutrientpoor) were selected to design the microcosm. The microcosms were contaminated with waste water inoculums for 24 hours. Total coliform and E. coli concentrations decreased during the first five days where as enterococci concentrations remained constant for all three sediments. Growth phase was observed between days 5-12 for the FIB. The FIB showed persistence up to 50 days. Lake Vidy showed the maximum increase in indicator organism concentration. This study confirms earlier studies that nutrient availability increases the survival of microbes especially for E. coli. Also, microorganisms have increased survival in sediments around coastal environments.
Particle association and transport of microbes.

Microbe-particle associations studies help identify which best management practice (BMPs) performs most efficiently to reduce the microbial load from upland sources like streets, parking lots etc. The runoff is usually collected by storm drainage systems to BMP sites. It was noted that microbe-particle associations occur at the initial site of particle mobilization and upland sedimentation-based BMPs maybe best suited to reduce microbial contamination (Krometis et al., 2009) . In two retention ponds studied, it was observed that microbial removal by settling does occur but not at the 60% efficiency recommended by U.S. EPA.

Although some E. coli and fecal coliform were removed by settling; enterococci and particles were not, probably due to resuspension events. The effect of water content, manure and aggregate size on the association of fecal coliforms to soil particles was also investigated (Guber et al., 2009) .
Association of fecal coliforms to soil showed a decrease with increase in water content or manure application.
Aggregate size did not affect microbial-soil interaction.

Fecal coliforms associated with air-dried aggregates showed different characteristics than water saturated aggregates, suggesting differences in bacterial transport mechanisms through the intra-aggregate pores. Slow processes like Brownian motion and chemotaxis were most likely to occur in water-saturated aggregates where as faster processes like capillary pressure gradient between suspended water and soil aggregates were responsible for bacterial transport in air-dried aggregates. A pathogen transport model was developed for Irish catchments using Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) (Coffey et al., 2009) (Rehmann and Soupir, 2009) . Bacterial transport by shoes and vehicle wheels can also spread microbial contamination as observed in a study done in Bethel, Alaska (Chambers et al., 2009 ).

Ten waste water treatment facilities with different filtration technologies were evaluated for presence of particles in the effluent water (Dietrich et al., 2009) . The results showed that particle concentration in water was above safety limits for drinking water following the U.S. EPA regulations. Specific pathogens have different association to particles with rotavirus being the most virulent with limit of 2 particles per 100 L of water. More advanced filtration technologies are needed to overcome these discrepancies.

Models were developed to predict E. coli concentrations along a peninsular beach complex in Lake Michigan (Nevers et al., 2009) . In Dorr County, Wisconsin, 24 beaches were studied and showed that beaches in northern Lake Michigan followed a spatial gradient with decreasing concentrations of E. coli with distance from Sturgeon Bay.
Beaches can be grouped according to proximity, presence of tidal creeks or storm run-offs and enclosures to predict fluctuations in pathogen levels.

Dogs, birds, shellfish and other animals contribute to the total microbial load at recreational beaches. Studies were conducted to compare the relative contribution of each of these non-point sources . Dog feces had the highest number of enterococci (3.9 x 10 7 CFU/g dry feces), followed by bird feces (3.7 x 10 5 CFU/g dry feces), and then in shrimp (2.0 CFU/g).
Camera image analysis was conducted to estimate the number of humans, dogs and birds that frequent the beach.

The human count on weekends was 1090 (including holiday weekends) and the average dogs visiting on weekends were 66. Therefore, the enterococci microbial load for the weekend was 2.1 x 10 11 CFU per fecal event, contributing significantly to the overall microbial load to the beach.

Contamination of recreational beaches were measured by FIB like E. coli or enterococci. Enterococci were especially important as indicators of total microbial load in marine beaches. The growth of enterococci in wet, unseeded beach sands was investigated by using microcosm columns A similar study was conducted to assess the persistence of fecal indicator bacteria in sand (Mika et al., 2009 ). Laboratory study was performed to investigate the effects of sunlight, raking and moisture on decay of FIB.

They observed that E. coli had a decay constant between -0.23 and -1.02 per day where as enterococci between -0.5 and -1.0 per day. It was observed that moisture did not play a significant role in the decay rate of enterococci. Both moistened and non-moistened microcosms showed similar decay rates for enterococci. However a significant difference between moistened and non-moistened microcosms was observed for E. coli. Sand temperature showed an influence on E. coli die-off rates. Decay rates increased rapidly at sand temperature of 50 o C and above.
Sunlight exposure did not have an effect on die-off rates.

Increased contact with beach sand results in greater susceptibility to diarrhea and gastrointestinal illness. A study was done to correlate the risk of illness among beachgoers with beach related activities. More than 26,000 beachgoers were interviewed during their beach visit followed up by telephonic interviews 10-12 days later (Heaney et al., 2009) . Digging in sand increased the risk of gastrointestinal illness 1.13 times and the risk of diarrhea 1.20 times. Children showed an increased risk of gastrointestinal illness compared to adults. Also, it was noted that being buried in sand statistically increased the risk of illness as compared to digging in sand. On the other hand, beachgoers contribute to the microbial load in beach sands. Studies showed that enterococci and Bacteroidales marker were released by both toddlers and adults at marine beaches In another study, water quality was examined at two recreational beaches on Lake Michigan during the peak swimming season (July-September) of 2004 (Wong et al., 2009

The correlation between indicator bacteria, viral indicators, pathogenic microorganisms and physical-chemical parameters was studied in the St. Lucie River Estuary (Ortega et al., 2009) . In indicator organisms, high correlations were observed between fecal and total coliform, somatic coliphages and total coliform, and total coliform, enterococci and E. coli. There was a negative correlation between indicator bacteria and salinity at the sites sampled. Most pathogenic organisms were below detection limits.
body_text.section: Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in estuaries.

body_text.text: The microbial load from different sources was studied at a tropical estuary in west coast of India (Nagvenkar and Ramaiah, 2009 Vibrio vulnificus were detected in less than an hour and with great sensitivity using specific primers for the cytolysin gene amplicon (Ren et al., 2009) . Primers for the cytolysin gene were tested on many other microbes including Vibrio spp., Aeromons spp., Pseudomonas spp.,
body_text.section: Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in estuaries.

body_text.text: and Shewanella algae which all resulted in a negative detection. The LAMP assay also demonstrated 10-fold more sensitivity than conventional PCR.
body_text.section: Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in estuaries.

body_text.text: A one-step, closed-tube LAMP reaction was developed for the detection of Entamoeba histolytica (Liang et al., 2009
body_text.section: Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in estuaries.

body_text.text: were some samples that were detected by conventional PCR but not by LAMP, concluding that due to its specific set of primers LAMP was extremely sensitive and a single nucleotide differences can alter its detection.

Cryptosporidium and Giardia (oo)cysts were investigated with a combination of a new ARAD microfiber filtration system and LAMP of the pathogenic strains (Plutzer and Tomor, 2009) . This system was able to detect at least 1 (oo)cyst in 10 L of drinking water sample.
The same EF-1 alpha primer was used for Giardia and SAM-1 gene primer was used for Cryptosporidium.

diagnostics. This section describes the development and/or optimization of array based tools for detection of multiple pathogens. This includes oligonucleotide arrays, multiple reaction PCR based platforms, and systems that combine both amplification and surface-based hybridization.
body_text.section: Array based genetic and phenotype based

body_text.text: Optimization included increasing sensitivity, implementing techniques for higher levels of automation, obtaining specificity at the strain level for genotyping, and reducing the time required to complete the assay. Some of these systems were not demonstrated for water based applications; however, there is high potential for implementing these techniques for detecting multiple water-borne pathogens simultaneously.
body_text.section: Array based genetic and phenotype based

body_text.text: Microarray based diagnostics allow diagnostics for thousands of assays simultaneously with a high level of specificity. Typical drawbacks of microarray include sample processing steps for labeling, low sensitivity, and large amount time required for hybridization compared to amplification based techniques. However, label-free, quantitative, and more sensitive microarray techniques have high potential for implementation into automated devices for water monitoring. For example, a microarray was described for detection of E. coli that allows label-free sample processing, and was both quantitative and sensitive (Donhauser et al., 2009 ). Prior to hybridization on the microarray, samples were amplified with primer sets (with biotin labels) targeting the uidA functional gene to increase sensitivity. Amplification was ceased during the logarithmic phase (after 25 cycles) of the reaction.

Stopping the amplification reaction during this phase allowed the starting amount of genomic copies to be quantified on the array. For label-free detection, a chemiluminesecne strategy was used which included incubation with streptavidin labeled horseradish peroxidase followed by luminol and hydrogen peroxide which causes light emission. An additional advantage of this label-free detection scheme compared to fluorescent dyes was that there was no background. Thus the sensitivity of this technique was higher than fluorescence based microarrays, and a detection limit of 40 copies per ml was observed. A Jin et al., 2009 , Hadjinicolaou et al., 2009 . The array was assembled using microchannels of PDMS filled with 250 µm beads immobilized with oligonucloetides, and a peristaltic pump was used for mesofluidic hybridization through the microchannels. Results showed that the maximum hybridization signal was obtained after 30 min for PCR products. Thus, this setup had higher hybridization efficiency compared to traditional microarray formats.

Including PCR amplification prior to hybridization, a detection limit of 500 to 6,000 CFU per ml was observed depending on the organism. Another array was developed by Brinkman and Fout (Brinkman and Fout, 2009 ) to genotype noroviruses in water; as a replacement to sequencing amplified products. Thirty-one probes targeting 24 bases sequences specific for GI.1, GI.2, GI.3, GI.4, GI.5, GII.1, GII.5, GII.6, GII.9 were designed from the RNA polymerase gene, and validated using 10 corresponding strains of norovirus. Results showed that the array had the specificity to discriminate between the tested strains of norovirus.

On chip amplification strategies that do not require a surface based hybridization have many benefits in that it combines the throughput of oligonucleotide microarray with the sensitivity of amplification. In addition, samples do not need to be amplified and labeled prior to testing, and time required for surface based hybridization was circumvented.

These advantages can reduce "hands-on-sample" and time required to complete the test. Thus, multiwell on-chip amplification based systems and surface bound amplification strategies were described frequently in 2009.

For example, a paper by Andersen and coauthors (Andresen et al., 2009) When testing simultaneous detection with both pathogens, the limit of detection was ten times less sensitive. While this sensitivity was not ideal, the authors proved the concept of helicase amplification on chip and describe the potential for obtaining a better detection limit.

Multiple well reaction chips can be limited by the chosen means of sample dispensing and sealing. An amplification chip with higher throughput was described by Liu and coauthors (Liu et al., 2009) Results showed sensitivity and quantitative values that were in agreement from those obtained using a commercial real-time thermocycler.

One drawback in using a multiple assay amplification chips was that all primers must have similar physicochemical properties to allow for identical temperature conditions. A software called hybseek was developed by Frech and coauthors (Frech et al., 2009) Using nested-PCR, a more sensitive detection of HuNoV and HAstV was achieved than the conventional PCR. Most common were HuNoV genotype GGII and Type 8 HAstV.

A study in Osaka, Japan focused on examining genotypes of Acanthamoeba and Naegleria species from tap-water sources (Edagawa et al., 2009) . The free living amoebae (FLA) were of great concern with regards to water contamination in this area. In a study, PCR was used to detect Bacteroidale,

Methanobrevibacter smithii in human sewage spiked into buffer, freshwater or marine water (Harwood et al., 2009) . Results indicated that the Bacteroidales assay was 100 more sensitive than the two others (10 -5 -10 -6 versus 10 -3 -10 -4 dilutions). However, the Bacteroidales assay was slightly less specific (96% versus 100%) than the M. smithii and HPyVs assays, and cross-reacted with 10% of dog and chicken feces samples.

Because of the sensitivity and specificity, these assays were considered to have good potential for MST. contained a third set of primers for internal amplification control. With this assay, the authors were able to identify fecal contamination in less than 5 hours, from 80% of water samples previously amended with cow, goat, pig sheep and other animal fecal samples. The sensitivity of the assay was 1.6-16 pg for uidA (10 2 -10 3 cells) and 1.6 pg for the animal DNA, revealing its good potential multiplex MST.

In another study from the same group, a TaqMan PCR assay was developed to evaluate pig fecal contamination in river water (Mieszkin et al., 2009) . Two pig-specific TaqMan probes were designed from pigspecific markers (Pig-1-Bac and Pig-2-Bac), obtained from a 16S rRNA gene Bacteroidales clone library from pig feces and slurry. The occurrence of these two new markers was measured at 14 different sites of a French river, and was compared with the occurrence of known human and ruminant specific markers (HF183 and BacR respectively).

Pig-1-Bac and Pig-2-Bac were detected at concentrations ranging between 3.6 and 4.1 log 10 copies per 100 mL in 25.0 and 62.5%, respectively, of the samples that were collected near pig farms; however these markers were detected near cattle farms. In contrast, human markers were detected (3.6 and 4.4 log 10 copies per 100 mL) in 90% of the samples that were collected near a residential area, and the bovine markers were detected (4.6 and 6.0 log 10 copies per 100 mL) in all samples collected near cattle farms. The study revealed the possibility to use these pig markers to detect pig fecal contamination, and the lower occurrence of these markers when compared to human and bovine markers.

Elsewhere, previously published qPCR assays targeting general, human-and bovine-specific Bacteroidales 16S rRNA gene markers (AllBac, BacR and HF8 respectively) were evaluated at the field scale in British rivers, bathing water and effluent (Stapleton et al., 2009
Existing TaqMan PCR assays were used to detect and distinguish universal, human-and cow-specific fecal

Bacteroidales, BacHum-UCD and HF283, and BacCow-UCD respectively) in The Njoro River in Kenya . Assays had 100% specificity but analytical sensitivity varied between 18 and 100%. For example, the sensitivity of Total Bacteroidales was 55% while that of BacUni-UCD was 100%, indicating the importance to select an appropriate marker. Similarly, in human sewage samples the sensitivity of BacHum-UCD was 0% while the sensitivity of HF183 was 80%. Application of these assays to the Njoro River revealed that the majority of fecal contamination in this watershed was coming from cows.

A method based on qPCR (targeting 16S rRNA gene of several bacteria), and partial least squares regression was used to compare gut microbiota of humans with that of several farm animals using fecal samples . The study showed that three dominant bacterial groups of the human gut microbiota have various levels in the different animals (Bacteroides, Bifidobacterium and Clostridium coccoides). For these reasons, the differential composition of these bacterial groups in water samples could be a good indicator of the origin of fecal contamination. Additionally, these bacterial groups are potential candidates for identifying new markers of human and eventually animal fecal contamination.

A Faecalibacterium 16S rRNA gene marker specific to human faces was identified using suppression substractive hybridization and bioinformatics, and was tested by PCR (Zheng et al., 2009) . Out of six sets of primers that were designed during that study, one was exclusively associated with human feces and allowed the detection of Faecalibacterium in 100% of sewage samples and 60.2% of human fecal samples. When fecal samples from various farm animals were used, no amplification was observed. Therefore, this new marker could be a good additional target to evaluate human fecal contamination using PCR or qPCR.

In another study, F + -specific coliphages were investigated as potential indicators for PCR or reverse transcriptase PCR-based MST in South Korea (Carroll et al., 2009 ). The ARPs of 1005 known E. coli isolates were characterized and used to differentiate human from non-human fecal contamination.

Discriminate analysis and partial least squares regression were used, respectively, (1) to discriminate the ARPs and therefore, to identify the source of contamination, and (2) to associate the positions of human sources isolates with specific sampling locations. Result revealed a good correlation between the rate of human isolates and the sampling location (i.e., the percentage was higher in urbanized sampling locations). However, results also indicated that the majority of fecal contamination was from animal origin.

In another study, the ratio of total Bifidobacteria (TB) to sorbitol-fermenting Bifidobacteria (SFB) was investigated to differentiate human from animal sources of fecal contamination (Ottoson 2009 ). The TB:SFB ratio was significantly higher in animal samples (>40) than in sewage

(1-17), at the exception of poultry manure which resulted in similar ratio than sewage. This study also revealed that TB:SFB ratio remains stable over time as the Bifidobacteria died at a rate of 0.16 and 0.58 log(day -1 ) at 4°C and 22°C respectively. Surprisingly, fecal coliforms disappeared at a slower rate than Bifidobacteria, but the ratio of fecal coliforms to SFB (FC:SFB) appeared to be inadequate for determining the sewage pollution inactivation.

FIGREF0.text: Introduction A review of the literature published in 2009 is presented on topics related to environmental occurrence and transport of fecal indicator bacteria (FIB) and pathogens in the environment, development and application of methods for detection, and microbial source tracking (MST) of fecal contamination. The section on occurrence and transport is organized into the following subsections: persistence and transport of FIB, particle association and transport of microbes, microbial quality of recreational beaches, occurrence of FIB and pathogens in watersheds, irrigation systems, estuaries, and wetlands, and novel indicators. In the section on detection methods, endpoint PCR and reverse transcription PCR, real-time PCR, loop mediated isothermal amplifications, array based genetic and phenotype based diagnostics which includes oligonucleotide arrays and genetic amplification arrays, and genotyping are discussed. The section on MST covers both genotypic and phenotypic MST methods. Environmental Occurrence, Persistence and Transport FIB are traditionally used to monitor the water quality for drinking and recreational activities. Understanding the behavior of FIB and pathogens in the environment is essential for assessing the human health risks and the environmental impacts. The following subsections of the research published in 2009 summarizes FIB and pathogens persistence, occurrence and transport and the impacts to recreational beaches, watersheds, irrigation systems, estuaries, and wetlands. In addition, the novel indicators that are being developed and evaluated. Persistence and transport of FIB. Several factors affect the persistence of fecal Bacteroides in surface

FIGREF1.text: Bacteroides vulgatus markers from pure cultures decayed faster in natural drinking water as compared to sterile water. The fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) counts of cells decreased below detection limit (< 1.4 x 10 4 cells/100 mL ) after 27 days in both sterile and drinking water. The DNA markers decreased below detection limit Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 885 after 200 days for drinking water but remained at near constant level for the entire experimental period of 230 days in sterile water. Wastewater inoculums were also used to test the persistence of Bacteroidales 16S rRNA gene markers. It was observed that decay of Bacteroidales markers from wastewater was much faster compared to pure cultures. Escherichia coli and coliforms showed a similar rate of decline by decreasing log-linearly for the first 21 days and then tapering off till the end of the incubation period of 31 days.

FIGREF2.text: Occurrence of FIB and pathogens inwatersheds. Storm water runoff is one of the significant factors contributing to contamination of surface waters. The removal of indicator bacteria in storm water by nine different BMPs were compared in Charlotte, NorthCarolina(Hathaway et al., 2009). The BMPs included one wet pond, two storm-water wetlands, two dry detention basins, one bioretention area and three proprietary devices.It was observed that one of the wetlands and the bioretention area was most efficient at reducing bacteria concentrations from the influent. The two dry detention basins performed the worst showing negative removal of fecal bacteria. Three urban watersheds in Santa Barbara, California showed a high concentration of both FIB and human-specific Bacteroides marker(Sercu et al., 2009).These high concentrations were sourced to storm events and storm drains that varied up to five orders of magnitude within the same day for human Bacteroides marker concentration.In another study, indicator bacteria levels in 15 streams in 11 watersheds in southern California were monitored through one year(Tiefenthaler et al., 2009). This helped to set reference levels of E. coli and enterococci during dry weather and non-storm conditions. There were seasonal fluctuations with highest levels of FIB occurring during June through August.Studies were conducted to investigate the origin and distribution of fecal contamination in a bay in Lake Geneva, Switzerland). There were 23 sampling sites within the bay and 3 point sources at the wastewater outlets for E. coli, enterococci and total coliform. The wastewater outlet, situated at a depth of 30 meters, contributed to maximum fecal contamination to the bay area. Microbial contamination shows a sharp increase during flood conditions and was subject to flow rate and temperature of the river. FIB profile examined across the vertical water column indicated that higher FIB levels were present at the hypolimnion at 25 m depth with relatively less contamination at the lake surface, thereby making the water relatively safe for recreation purposes. Studies were also done to evaluate the sediments of the Bay of Vidy, Lake Geneva, Switzerland). E. coli and enterococci concentrations were around 3.1 X 10 5 CFU/g and 1.2 x 10 5 CFU/g respectively. There was a decrease of E. coli and enterococci with depth in the vertical sediment profile from 10 6 CFU at the surface to about 10 4 -10 5 CFU at 10 cm below the surface. Sediments near the waste water treatment plant outlet were monitored for 90 days and showed no decrease in FIB concentration with time. This suggests sediments act as reservoirs of fecal contamination.The Thomas-Brook watershed in Canada was monitored for fecal indicators and total suspended solids to study the spatial and temporal patterns of microbial load from five sub-watersheds(Sinclair et al., 2009). It was observed that runoff from agricultural activity contributed to higher bacterial load than residential runoff. Also, higherWater Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 889 concentrations of FIB were noted during storm events and in years with higher cumulative precipitation. Similarly, the occurrence of somatic coliphages, F+ specific RNA bacteriophages, and conventional indicator bacteria were examined over five locations of Swist river, Germany (Franke et al., 2009). River samples were taken over a year and surface runoff samples were taken in the same position after rainfall events. There was a high correlation between concentration of somatic coliphages and land use. The lowest median concentrations of somatic phages were detected where forests (400 PFU/l) surrounded the river while the highest median concentration was found around farmland (591,000 PFU/l). The median concentrations of F+ specific RNA bacteriophages in the river did not vary significantly to land use. In addition, indicator bacteria were not able to significantly correlate to the detection of coliphages and for human pathogen viruses. Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in irrigation systems. In a study conducted in the South Nation River Basin in eastern Ontario, Canada, water samples were analyzed for pathogenic bacteria (Listeria monocytogenes, E. coli O157:H7, Salmonella spp., Campylobacter spp.), parasites (Cryptosporidium and Giardia) and indicator bacteria (E. coli, enterococci, total coliforms and C. perfringens) (Wilkes et al., 2009). There was significant relation of pathogenic bacteria with indicator bacteria. Salmonella showed significant positive correlations at all seasons where as Campylobacter and L. monocytogenes had highest correlation during spring-summer. Cryptosporidium cysts showed significant correlation with indicator bacteria during winter where as Giardia showed less correlation with negative correlation in a few cases. The occurrence of enteric viruses in groundwater used for irrigation located in Gyeonggi Province, South Korea, was monitored with reverse transcription PCR and cell culture PCR (Cheong et al., 2009). PCR based assays were developed to detect adenoviruses, enteroviruses, noroviruses and rotaviruses. 17% of the groundwater samples collected were positive with adenoviruses and enteroviruses. However, noroviruses and rotaviruses were not detected in any of the samples. Results also showed that frequency levels of total coliforms, fecal coliforms and enterococci were below the frequency of the viruses in the groundwater samples. Since the occurrence of enteric viruses were not correlated with the levels of indicator bacteria, viral contamination of irrigation water may be undetected and present a potential risk to human health.

FIGREF3.text: described the development of an on-chip isothermal amplification device that used helicase to denature DNA without the 95 degree temperature step used in thermocycling. One of the primers was attached to the surface of the array, and the primer in solution was labeled with Cy5. The device was tested using assays targeting the mecA gene of S. aureus and the piv Ng gene of N. gonorrhoeae. After a 120 min helicase amplification reaction at 65 o C, the slides were washed and scanned. The limit of detection for S. aureus was 250 pg of genomic DNA and 1 ng of genomic DNA for N. gonorrhoeae.

TABREF0.text: . There are several parameters and input information required to effectively predict the movement of bacteria through a watershed. However, it is able to identify periods of heightened pathogen Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 886 concentration thereby monitoring Irish water catchments. Rehmann et al. (2009) developed a model to predict the interactions between sediments and water column for the transport of microorganisms. This model incorporates two parameters -the Damkohler number and the sediment interaction parameter that include flow, sediment transport, and growth of microbes. The model can accurately predict earlier field measurements in streams

TABREF1.text: ). Experimental results showed that culturable enterococci and total enterococci concentrations increased at a rate of 0.20 day -1 and 0.63 day -1 , respectively, when moisture was added to nonsterile unseeded sand obtained from Lovers Point in California. This study further proves that enterococci multiply in the environment thus violating an important property of indicator organisms; caution must be taken Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 887 while interpreting results of indicator organisms during the monitoring of marine beaches.

TABREF2.text: Gull fecal contamination is prevalent in beach waters of the Great Lakes. Gull feces contain many pathogenic bacteria including Salmonella, Campylobacter, Aeromonas, and Yersinia. Gull feces showed a consistent presence of Bacteroidales when screened by PCR (Jeter et al., 2009). Sequencing of the gene library clones of the fecal samples showed that there was greater diversity at the species level; gulls from northern Lake Michigan had greater numbers of Bacteroides and Prevotella sp. where as those from southern Lake Michigan had a greater amount of sequences of Parabacteroides and Bacteroides genera

TABREF4.text: ). Estuarine environments Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 890 were affected by outfalls from sewage drainage, storm events and land drains. The average concentrations for total coliforms, total streptococci, E. coli, Vibrio cholerae, Salmonella spp., Streptococcus faecalis and Aeromonas The presence of hepatitis A and norovirus was investigated in Huizache Caimanero Lagunary Complex, Mexico, one of the most productive natural systems for shrimp cultivation (Hernandez-Morga et al., 2009). Forty estuarine water samples were collected monthly between September 2006 and April 2007 and analyzed using ultrafiltration with reverse transcriptase PCR. Hepatitis A and norovirus were identified in 80% and 70% of the samples respectively. Both viruses were present during shrimp harvest season which poses a health risk to consumers of marine products. Also there was not an association between viruses with respect to fecal coliforms and E. coli; detection of these indicators in the samples were 49% and 34% respectively.Occurrence of FIB and pathogens in wetlands.Wetlands are often used as tertiary wastewater treatments for reuse of reclaimed water. Wetlands can remove human pathogens by sedimentation, attachment to plant roots, UV radiation and predation by protozoa. The efficiency of subsurface flow (SSF) and free-surface flow (FSF) constructed horizontal wetlands were evaluated for efficiency at removal of microorganisms from waste water(Graczyk et al., 2009). It was seen that SSF wetland performed better than the FSF wetlands with a pathogen removal efficiency of 30.9%. The three FSF wetlands had negative efficiency of -96.6%, -63.4% and -92.1%    implying that the effluent had higher concentrations of pathogens compared to the influent. This indicates that wetlands add pathogenic microorganisms from wildlife and birds, therefore, this form of tertiary treatment need to be reconsidered. However in a similar study using a marshland upwelling system in Louisiana, it was observed that fecal bacteria from waste water completely died off in four months).Vegetation can act as buffers to prevent transport of fecal contaminated rain water from polluting surface water drainages and reservoirs. Three herbage species, white clover, orchard grass and perennial ryegrass, at three canopy heights (short, medium and tall) were evaluated for their efficiency to disperse fecal bacteria in rain from an artificial rain device(Boyer and Belesky, 2009). White clover at the short canopy level demonstrated the greatest dispersion of fecal coliforms.Enterococcus gave the best results with no false positives when using the Luminex method). Human specific bacterial marker genes that worked well with qPCR were the Enterococcus esp marker and the Bacteroides thetaiotamicron. The Luminex method worked Methanobrevibacter smithii. However repeatability for M. smithii was poor. A study was carried out to evaluate the water in a high-altitude system receiving wastewater that was used for Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 891 irrigation and drinking in Mexico City for the presence of enterovirus, rotavirus, astrovirus, coliphages and indicator bacteria(Espinosa et al., 2009). The irrigation water was positive for fecal indicator bacteria including fecal coliforms, enterococci and total coliforms. Coliphages corresponded most closely with the presence of FIB in the samples. In the drinking water samples no viruses were detected before chlorination. However fecal indicator bacteria were found with enterococci being the most frequent. Therefore, adequate disinfection treatment of wastewater was required for reuse as drinking water. Also, this study confirms coliphages can be used as alternate indicators of fecal contamination. Wastewater reused for irrigation should have coliforms within the acceptable limits of <1000 CFU as specified by WHO but this limit was exceeded in the present study area.Alternative indicators that are being considered include coliphages, human specific marker in Bacteroidales and human viruses. Sunlight inactivation of indicator bacteria was investigated at a sewage polluted marine beach. Concentrations of each organism measured during the day and night showed that occurrence was higher during light hours than dark hours except for the human Bacteroidales marker and enterovirus markers. The organisms tested included E. coli, enterococci, somatic coliphages, human enterovirus and human adenovirus. They also developed empirical models to determine the rates of sunlight inactivation for the various indicator microorganisms. From these models, the rates of sunlight inactivation for enterococci, E. coli and species including Salmonella enteritidis and S.typhimurium(Hadjinicolaou et al., 2009). Three sets of primers were used for the amplification of invA, prot6E, and fliC genes. Salmonella species were collected from Rad) with standard cycling conditions. The assay was able to detect single DNA copy from ten-fold serial dilutions of 1×10 4 to 1 cyst. Additionally, the primers were found to be highly specific, when tested against negative strains of C.

TABREF9.text: CryptoPMA-PCR assay was developed to detect viability and genotypes of Cryptosporidium which USEPA methods do not detect. Treatment with propidium monoazide (PMA) helps prevent DNA amplification from dead oocysts, while allowing downstream genotyping studies for live oocysts within a mixed population. The early stage method has been tested for SSU rRNA gene amplicon and hsp 70 gene. In 2009, the research related to microbial source tracking (MST) essentially focused on genotypic strategies targeting indicators of human and farm animals fecal pollution. These molecular strategies generally used PCR or qPCR to determine the difference in indicator composition in various sources of fecal contamination. However, phenotypic strategies including antibiotic resistance profiling were also used. methods used in 2009 for MST were essentially based on PCR and qPCR. Among the various fecal indicator tested, a lot attention was concentrated on targeting specific in the 16S rRNA genes that are specific to Bacteroidales and Bifidobacterium coming from human or animal fecal contamination.

TABREF10.text: In a similar study, three ruminant-specific assays were developed and compared to one existing ruminantspecific and five human-specific assays, all targeting the 16S rRNA gene of Bacteroidales or Bifidobacteriun(Dorai-Raj et al., 2009). Results indicated that the three novel PCR assays were more sensitive than the existing Bacteroidales assay (52-87% versus 17%) for MST in rural water samples. In addition, the human-specific assay Water Environment Research, Volume 82, Number 10-Copyright © 2010 Water Environment Federation 900 targeting Bifidobacterium catenulatum appeared to be the most promising one with sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 87%.The uptake, persistence and accumulation of human-associated Enterococcus in the mussel Mytelus edulis was investigated using PCR targeting the human specific markers M66 of E. faecalis and esp of E. faecium(Roslev et al., 2009). The study revealed that M. edulis could accumulate human-associated Enteroccocus markers for up to 120 hours after fecal contamination, making these makers good candidates for MST of human fecal contamination in mussels.The rapid detection and discrimination of agricultural fecal contamination was investigated using a multiplex PCR assay targeting E. coli uidA gene and a 124bp conserved region obtained from an alignment of bovine, caprine, ovine and porcine cytochrome B genomic sequences(Baker-Austin et al., 2009). The test also

TABREF11.text: ). Results indicated the absence of significant correlation between the different sources of water and the occurrence of Bacteroidales specific markers. Therefore the study concluded that tracking Bacteroidales was not in compliance with an efficient MST of fecal indicator organisms. However, only one set of primers/probe was used per marker and no comparison was made with other primers targeting the same or eventually other markers. TABREF12.text: ). Using RNase sensitivity assays, PCR, reverse transcriptase PCR and nucleic acids sequencing, 311 F + coliphages were characterized. Results indicated that F + RNA coliphages were more prevalent in geese than in cow (95% versus 5%). In addition, F + RNA coliphages isolated from human wastewater belong to different groups than coliphages isolated from animals feces (groups II and III, and group I and IV, respectively). UniFrac significance statistical analysis and principal coordinate analysis were used to confirm the results and show that the F + RNA coliphages isolated from human and animals were significantly different. In contrast, no significant difference was found between F + DNA isolated from human and animal sources revealing that coliphage-based MST can be performed efficiently only if the appropriate coliphage (F + RNA) is used. methods. A few library-dependent methods including antibiotic resistance profiling and ratio Bifidobacteria, were used in 2009.
